segments.text: The safety center you see on the door here is kind of an interesting thing.
I got involved in the chemical process safety area, I guess, about four years ago.
A fellow who is now retired used to be head of the safety engineering program in industrial engineering, Ralph Vernon.
I don't know if you knew that.
I think I do.
That's been a really good program, hasn't it?
Well, it's kind of ironic because it wasn't.
an independent degree program.
And then they kind of downgraded it just to an option in the IE program.
And then they transferred it to nuclear engineering because they had a radiological safety program there.
So they combined it with that.
So it's been kind of disbursed over the recent years.
They still have some IE people teaching some undergraduate courses, but the graduate program is centered in nuclear engineering.
But there's been a market for those kind of people, hasn't there?
There has been a demand.
And Ralph, back in about four years ago, had, and I don't know how he got it, but he got a contract with Pertamina Oil Company in Indonesia for teaching a safety program to 24 Indonesian engineers.
This is a 10-week program in the summertime.
And he was looking for help.
And I'd known Ralph for a while.
We always talked informally and stuff.
So he told me about it.
And about that time, there was a book, a new book that came out.
The chemical engineering program was emphasizing process safety.
And the AICHE was pushing this.
They have a center for chemical process safety and all of that.
And there was a book that came out on that subject.
And I was interested in the book.
So I volunteered.
to teach chemical process safety to these Indonesian engineers.
So I helped Ralph teach these guys.
And I set up some field trips for them to different companies around.
And I went through that whole book.
And I saw that this was a really significant, important topic in the profession and in the industry.
So I put it in as an elective course.
It took me about two or three years to get it in, because at the time, Blumefeld was head of the department.
And we were kind of in a bind to meet our required teaching loads with our required courses.
So he wasn't inclined to add another elective course.
So he first told me that I couldn't teach it unless I thought it was an overload.
But I volunteered to teach it as an overload.
That's a nice offer, isn't it?
Yeah.
But you did.
You did do it.
I did.
I taught it as an overload the first time.
And it went over pretty well.
So we put it in as a permanent course.
And then about a year later,

I got this letter in the mail from a lawyer in Houston who said he had a client who he couldn't name, but he was interested in supporting an educational program across the state, wanted to know what we had going.
So I wrote him.
I responded.
I told him what I was doing in the course and something about the safety program here and all of that.
And I didn't get a response, so I forgot about it.
And about a year later,
Then I got another letter saying that Mr. T. Michael O'Connor would like to set up his endowed program here at A&M.
And T. Michael O'Connor is not the one who's on the Board of Regents.
We have a T. Michael O'Connor on the Regents, but this is another fellow who was a chemical engineering graduate from the University of Missouri at Rolla.
And his wife is also a chemical engineering graduate from the University of Missouri at Columbia.
And he was working for Kellogg at the time.
And his wife was working for Phillips.
And she was killed in the Phillips explosion in Pasadena in 1989.
And there was 23 people killed in that explosion.
And most of them participated in the class action lawsuit against Phillips.
But Mike O'Connor didn't.
Being a chem engineer, he did extra homework to find out what went wrong and what they couldn't do right and all of that.
and he filed his own independent lawsuit.
That's why the lawyer couldn't tell me who it was in the beginning, because the lawsuit was still pending.
Well, it ended up that he got a $40 million settlement from that lawsuit, and he dedicated $4 million of that to education and process safety, which he put aside in a private foundation.
And the proceeds are now coming to us here.
The money that's generated by the interest from that endowment is coming here to support the program.
But this is good and bad.
It's obviously good to have this resource.
The bad part about it is that process safety is not a traditional research area for chemical engineering.
It's much more applied.
It's industrial oriented.
In fact, I just served as the chairman for a plant process safety symposium sponsored by AICH in Houston on the 1st of April.
We had over 500 attendees, 30 technical sessions, a bunch of exhibitors.
I think I was the only academic involved in the whole meeting.
The rest of them were industrial people from all over the world, but they were all industrial people.
I'm sure with environmental law and safety law, they're in liability and all that stuff.
It's a very hot area in the industry, but there's no programs in NSF to support it.
So it's not easy getting funding support from traditional research support areas.
But we recently have gotten a grant from the Design Institute for Emergency Relief Systems, which is an informal industrial group
sponsored by the AICHE that's dedicated to developing design procedures for emergency relief pressure vessels.
And a lot of these pressure vessels are chemical reactors that, when the reaction takes off and runs away, then stuff comes out to the leak lane.
And you have to be able to design these things to properly size them to handle the flow rates so the pressure doesn't run beyond the second level.
Nobody knows how to do this properly because, you know, this is an unsteady state, multi-phase, non-isothermal, you know, a very complicated system that these things take on.
And so the design institute had actually put together a design manual and a computer program for doing this, and they made some money from that.
And so they put out some RFPs, request for proposals for research,
for high-viscosity, multi-phase flows through the leaf systems.

So meanwhile, I had, with some of the contacts I made through this symposium, another fellow who was president of the South Texas AICHE interested in this area, who's actually also chairman of the Chemical Engineering Advisory Committee for Prairie View, as a matter of fact.
They've been trying to push Prairie View to get involved in research in this area.
And then I came on the same, and it was obvious I had

direct interest in this area so i teamed up with them and five or six companies and we competed for this grant from this naira institute apparently they've been there as long as i've been here yeah it's had a very spotty history up and down a lot of changes in personnel and administration
It's not been too stable over the years, but it's been there.
And I think it's getting better, but it still has a ways to go.
They don't have much of a graduate program.
They do have some master's students.
So myself and a fellow in mechanical engineering, a fellow who's head in Prairie View,
two companies that have test facilities that make these relief valves and testing and evaluating are in a consortium group that we did on this contract, and we got it.
And so we're now getting started to that.
And Dr. Patrick has been officially signed with NASA.
The only project I have to complain about is the Hilton Johnson Space Center.
And NASA has a...
term, and it's not human engineering, but anyway, it has to do with safety and adaptation of systems first.
The human...
They call it ergonomics.
Part of that, like a chair, an ergonomic chair.
They're really conscious of that.
Because, of course, in that, safety...
preservation and duplicate systems and self-redundant systems and what have you.
One of the problems I have when I say process safety, we have the safety engineering program here at A&M already, which really is basically industrial hygiene things.
Industrial hygiene is more personnel safety, protection from hazardous environment and that sort of thing, whereas process safety is how to make the plants and processes and equipment safe.
So there's a lot more engineering design involved, like sizing these relief valves.

And the government guidelines now require, OSHA and EPA guidelines require all companies that handle certain amounts of any hazardous material to have not only training programs, but they have to estimate

what happens, scenarios, if pipes would break or vessels would rupture, how much of this stuff would be released, at what rate, where it would go, what would be the concentrations and the consequences and the effects, so vapor cloud dispersion modeling, release rates, relief systems, all of that, and how to design processes that are inherently safer using less severe conditions, less negative materials and things like that.
This is all process safety.
In fact, AICHE has the Center for Chemical Process Safety, which in turn has a national committee whose objective is to integrate process safety topics into the chemical engineering curriculum.
And I'm a member of that committee.
And all of us are developing teaching modules that incorporate various process safety topics in process control and committees and fluid mechanics and stoichiometry and all those.
It looks like all those blue books on the shelf behind you are examples of these teaching modules that we've developed.
Would you say most of your students that you've been here go into refining, protein-related industries?
Well, historically, the petrochemical industry has been the main employee of the chemical engineers.
But that's gradually shifting.
In fact, in the early 80s, we had a downturn in employment
petrochemical industry.
At that time, a lot of them were taken up by companies like pulp and paper companies or foods and pharmaceuticals and that.
In recent times, a very hot area has been electronic processing, making solid state wafers, silicon wafers, and IC circuits.
There's a lot of chemical processes not only involved with
making the wafers, but actually making the circuits by etching and diffusion and things like that, which are chemical processes.
So those companies finally realized that chemical engineers know a lot and can benefit from it.
Good.
That's good.
Well, Ron, I don't want to keep you any longer today, since we've done a lot.
But I'd like to come back at you, possibly, sometime.
I'm going to take my time doing this.
Could I get from you, you have to have a copy of your vita sometimes.
Do you have any information on the safety processing brochure or something?
Let me see you all.
Thank you very much.
